messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] structure, unschooling, relaxing
messages.msgSnippet: ... That s what I was thinking - that maybe you re putting the cart before the horse? Maybe concentrate on making what you do really enjoyable, giving the kids
messages.messageBody:
On Sep 27, 2005, at 7:44 AM, SandraDodd@... wrote:

> If your husband cares whether kids watch a movie or play a computer
> game
> before 5:00 as opposed to after 5:00, he was not NEARLY ready for
> eliminating
> bedtimes.
>

That's what I was thinking - that maybe you're putting the cart
before the horse?

Maybe concentrate on making what you do really enjoyable, giving the
kids a greater and greater voice in it?

For example, SAXON MATH??? I just cannot imagine a 9 year old
choosing Saxon 5/4 over all the absolutely WONDERFUL math materials
out there in the world.

Look at <www.livingmath.net>.

Julie Brennan - homeschooling mom in San Diego - has the best math
website in the world there.

-pam



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] structure, unschooling, relaxing
messages.msgSnippet: SandraDodd@aol.com wrote: -=-That was a LOT of formal education, not a little.-=- -=-Compared to math-at-9:00, reading-at-10:00 it s not very structured, but
messages.messageBody:
SandraDodd@... wrote:

-=-That was a LOT of formal education, not a little.-=-
-=-Compared to math-at-9:00, reading-at-10:00 it's not very structured, but compared to unschooling, it's EXTREMELY structured.-=-



I know, but we WERE math-at-9:00, reading-at-10:00, so this is a HUGE step forward for us. I would love to just drop all lessons completely, but it was like pulling teeth to get my husband to agree to even the relaxed version of things...unschooling is going to take him a while longer. I would like to just do things my way, but I have to consider his feelings and input even if I don't always agree.



-=-If your husband cares whether kids watch a movie or play a computer game before 5:00 as opposed to after 5:00, he was not NEARLY ready for eliminating bedtimes.-=-



It's funny, but that is the thing he has had the least problem with. He just can't/won't believe that the kids will choose wisely if allowed to choose what to learn. But we are making progress...


-=-Maybe you should buy Rue Kream's new book. It might be what you both could use.-=-



This book sounds great. It seems like it addresses a lot of ideas that books like Homeschooling Our Children, Unschooling Ourselves didn't. Thanks



Rebecca




---------------------------------
Yahoo! for Good

messages.subject: structure, unschooling, relaxing
messages.msgSnippet: ... That was a LOT of formal education, not a little. -=-So we re not very structured and if there is something more interesting going on, or if the boys are
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 9/27/05 6:53:19 AM, rjpbenson@... writes:


> That's pretty much it.
>

That was a LOT of formal education, not a little.

-=-So we're not very structured and if there is something more interesting
going on, or if the boys are reading a good book that they just can't put down
or are playing a game (not a video game or watching TV because my husband is
still against these things before 5pm), then we'll just skip "lessons" for the
day.-=-

Compared to math-at-9:00, reading-at-10:00 it's not very structured, but
compared to unschooling, it's EXTREMELY structured.

If your husband cares whether kids watch a movie or play a computer game
before 5:00 as opposed to after 5:00, he was not NEARLY ready for eliminating
bedtimes.

Maybe you should buy Rue Kream's new book. It might be what you both could
use.
http://www.freechild.info/

Sandra


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
